title: IS Colombia a good U.S. ally?

content: At one time, America had very close, and good ties with Columbia. We did a lot there to help slow down the drug trade and try to help the people switch to cash crops that fed people, rather than addict people to drugs. But all that ended and faded when Reagan was replaced with Clintoon as President here. The people of Columbia are great people, and it would be great if America and Columbia kept close, friendly economic ties - - Wandering and Wondering

content: Any country appears to be a friend of the USA as long as we continue to pump millions of dollars into their hands. Try not giving them money and see how long they call us friends.

title: IS Colombia a good U.S. ally?
IS Colombia a good U.S. ally?

content: Columbia, like most sovereign states, has its own interests and priorities. It has some issues with crime in general, organized crime, and especially drug lords/gangs, so it's accepted help from us in the form of helicopters and training and so forth in combating that. However, U.S. policy has for the past 15 or 20 years been one of benign neglect, in regards to most countries south of our border. In light of this vacuum, regional personalities like Hugo Chavez have begun to have a larger influence on the populations of neighboring countries, including Columbia. That guy's influential because his country has oil, and he's pretty adamantly anti-U.S., though I suspect this stance is largely status or attention-seeking. There aren't terribly many illegal immigrants from south of Central America, statistically speaking. I mean, there's some, of course, just not terribly many. That's all I got from my semi-regular reading of and listening to the international news and a short tourist visit to Argentina, as far as Columbia goes.
